facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 696 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 696 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 13, 1963 of Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 10 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. IO of 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Ramaswami, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J.

facts.text: Respondent purchased business from Purushottam Raju by registered instrument dated October 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent purchased, by a registered instrument dated October 5, 1956, the business carried on by one Purushottam Raju under the name-All India Trading Company.

facts.text: Purushottam Raju was sole proprietor of All India Trading Company.

anchor.surface_text: the business carried on by one Purushottam Raju under the name-All India Trading Company. Purushottam Raju was the sole proprietor of the business

facts.text: Purushottam Raju assessed to sales-tax for years 1948-49 and 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: Purushottam Raju was the sole proprietor of the business and had been assessed to sales-tax in respect of his turnover for the years 1948-49 and 1949-50.

facts.text: Arrears of sales-tax: Rs. 3836-4-0 for 1948-49 and Rs. 1218-1-9 for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee paid some amounts towards sales-tax thus determined, but there remained some arrears of sales-tax i.e., Rs. 3836-4-0 for 1948-49 and Rs. 1218-1-9 for 1949-50.

facts.text: Sales-tax authorities attempted to recover arrears from respondent as purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales-tax authorities attempted to recover the arrears of tax from the respondent as the purchaser of the business.

facts.text: Respondent denied liability to pay sales-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent 6 63 denied liability to pay sales-tax but his companytention was over-ruled by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer.

facts.text: Deputy Commercial Tax Officer overruled respondent's contention.

anchor.surface_text: denied liability to pay sales-tax but his companytention was over-ruled by the Deputy Commercial Tax Officer.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Commercial Tax Officer, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Commercial Tax Officer as well as to the Board of Revenue, but the appeals were dismissed.

facts.text: Appeals to Board of Revenue dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Commercial Tax Officer as well as to the Board of Revenue, but the appeals were dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Madras High Court for certiorari to quash orders of Commercial Tax Officer and Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter moved the Madras High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of certiorari to quash the orders of the Commercial Tax Officer and the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: Ganapati Pillai J dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: Ganapatia Pillai, J. who heard the petition dismissed it.

facts.text: Respondent appealed under Letters Patent to Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took the matter in appeal under the Letters Patent.

facts.text: Division Bench: S. Ramachandra Iyer, C.J. and Ramakrishnan, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench companysisting of S. Ramachandra Iyer, C.J. and Ramakrishnan, J. reversed the judgment of the Single Judge

facts.text: Division Bench reversed single judge, held Rule 21-A illegal and ultra vires, respondent not liable.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench companysisting of S. Ramachandra Iyer, C.J. and Ramakrishnan, J. reversed the judgment of the Single Judge, holding that Rule 21-A of the Sales-Tax Rules was illegal and ultra vires and the respondent was number liable to pay the sales-tax due from his predecessor in-title, Purushottam Raju.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave from Division Bench judgment dated September 13, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the Division Bench of the Madras High Court dated September 13, 1963 in Writ Appeal No. 10 of 1962.

facts.text: Rule 21-A framed by State Government under s.19(1) and (2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 21-A was framed by the State Government under the rule- making power granted to it under s. 19 1  and  2  of the Act.

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 (Act No. IX of 1939).

anchor.surface_text: the purchaser of business carried on by a dealer as defined in the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939  Madras Act No. IX of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act,

facts.text: 3rd Amendment Act, 1956 (Act No. XV of 1956) assented by President on October 1, 1956, published October 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The 3rd Amendment Act, 1956 received the assent of the President on October 1, 1956 but it was published in the Madras Gazette on October 8. 1956.

facts.text: Transfer instrument dated October 5, 1956, before publication of 1956 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the registered instrument by which the business was transferred to the respondent is dated October 5, 1956 and the amending Act has therefore numberapplication.

facts.text: Amending Act of 1959 inserted express provision making transferee liable for arrears.

anchor.surface_text: By the amending Act of 1959  Act 1 of 1959  an express provision was inserted by which the transferee of the business was made liable for the arrears of sales-tax due from the transferor.

facts.text: Respondent disputed any undertaking to pay arrears of sales-tax in the transfer instrument.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, disputed by Mr. Ganapathy Iyer on behalf of the respondent that there was any undertaking on the part of the respondent to discharge the liabilities in regard to arrears of sales- tax.
under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ in the nature of certiorari to quash the orders of the Commercial Tax Officer and the Board of Revenue.

issues.text: The question of law involved in this appeal is whether the purchaser of business carried on by a dealer as defined in the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939, hereinafter called the Act, can be made liable for arrears of sales-tax due from the dealer in respect of transactions of sale which took place before the transfer of the business under Rule 21-A of the Rules framed in exercise of the powers conferred on the State Government by s. 19 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law involved in this appeal is whether the purchaser of business carried on by a dealer as defined in the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939  Madras Act No. IX of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act, can be made liable for arrears of sales-tax due from the dealer in respect of transactions of sale which took place before the, transfer of the business under Rule 21-A of the Rules framed in exercise of the powers companyferred on the State Government by s. 19 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered in this appeal is whether Rule 21-A is intra vires of the power of the State Government under ss. 19 1  and  2  of the Act.

holdings.text: Rule 21-A is beyond the rule-making power of the State Government either under s. 19(1) or s. 19(2)(c) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that Rule 21-A is beyond the rule-making power of the State Government either under s. 19 1  or s. 19 2  c  of the Act. It was then submitted by Mr. Ram Reddy that Rule 21-A may be supported by the language of s. 10 1  of the Act which states Payment and recovery of tax.- 1  The tax assessed under this Act shall be paid

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.19(1) limited to carrying out purposes of Act without enlarging s.10 recovery or creating liability on non-dealer; s.19(2)(c) 'assessment' means tax computation/determination per precedents, not recovery from third parties

holdings.text: Rule 21-A is ultra vires of the rule-making power of the State Government under the Act

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the argument of the appellants on this aspect of the case and hold that Rule 21-A is ultra vires of the rule-making power of the State Government under the, Act. It was next argued on behalf of the appellants that upon a true construction of the registered instrument dated October 5, 1956 the respondent undertook to pay not only Sch. I liabilities but also other liabilities like sales-tax imposed in regard to the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(1) as argued not applicable as 3rd Amendment Act 1956 creating charge on properties published Oct 8 1956 after transfer on Oct 5 1956 per Madras General Clauses Act s.5(1)

holdings.text: the amending Act has therefore no application

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the registered instrument by which the business was transferred to the respondent is dated October 5, 1956 and the amending Act has therefore no application. We accordingly reject the argument of the appellants on this aspect of the case and hold that Rule 21-A is ultra vires of the rule-making power of the State Government under the, Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 3rd Amendment Act assented Oct 1 but published Oct 8 1956; comes into force on publication date per s.5(1) Madras General Clauses Act as no other date specified

holdings.text: even on the assumption that the respondent undertook to pay the arrears of sales-tax due by the transferor, it does not follow that there is a liability created inter se between the State Government on the one hand and the transferee on the other hand

anchor.surface_text: But even on the assumption that the respondent undertook to pay the arrears of sales-tax due by the transferor, it does not follow 66 7 that there is a liability created inter se between the State Government on the one hand and the transferee on the other hand. To put it differently, it is not open to the State Government to rely on the instrument inter vivos between the transferor and the transferee

holdings.reasoning_summary: No privity of contract; State not party to transfer instrument between transferor and transferee, cannot enforce any undertaking therein

holdings.text: the judgment of the Division Bench of the High Court dated September 13, 1963 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the argument of the appellants on this aspect of the case also. For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Division Bench of the High Court dated September 13, 1963 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 21-A ultra vires; no other basis for transferee liability including s.10 or contract; affirms High Court that respondent not liable for predecessor's sales-tax arrears

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the argument of the appellants on this aspect of the case and hold that Rule 21-A is ultra vires of the rule-making power of the State Government under the, Act. edges.explanation: Holding that amending Act has no application directly addresses issue of whether it was in operation before transfer

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the registered instrument by which the business was transferred to the respondent is dated October 5, 1956 and the amending Act has therefore no application. We accordingly reject the argument of the appellants on this aspect of the case and hold that Rule 21-A is ultra vires of the rule-making power of the State Government under the, Act.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Division Bench of the High Court dated September 13, 1963 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed with company

But even on the assumption that the respondent undertook to pay the arrears of sales-tax due by the transferor, it does not follow 66 7 that there is a liability created inter se between the State Government on the one hand and the transferee on the other hand. To put it differently, it is not open to the State Government to rely on the instrument inter vivos between the transferor and the transferee
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Division Bench of the High Court dated September 13, 1963 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed with company

We accordingly reject the argument of the appellants on this aspect of the case also. For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Division Bench of the High Court dated September 13, 1963 is correct and this appeal must be dismissed with costs.
For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the Division Bench of the High Court dated September 13, 1963 is companyrect and this appeal must be dismissed with company
